extendedIngredients.name: oregano
extendedIngredients.original: 2 tsps chopped fresh oregano (may substitute1 tsp dried)
extendedIngredients.originalName: chopped fresh oregano (may substitute1 tsp dried)

extendedIngredients.name: swordfish steaks
extendedIngredients.original: 2 lbs swordfish steaks , cut 1/2 inch thick

title: Grilled Swordfish Sicilian-style
summary: Need a caveman, gluten free, dairy free, and primal main course? Grilled Swordfish Sicilian-style could be a great recipe to try. This recipe serves 1 and costs $21.21 per serving. One serving contains 1801 calories, 179g of protein, and 115g of fat. Only a few people made this recipe, and 1 would say it hit the spot. It is perfect for The Fourth Of July. Head to the store and pick up ground pepper, lemon juice, swordfish steaks, and a few other things to make it today. To use up the table salt you could follow this main course with the Chocolate Chip Banana Bread Plus Sweet Banana Roundup as a dessert. From preparation to the plate, this recipe takes roughly 15 minutes. It is brought to you by Recipezaar. All things considered, we decided this recipe deserves a spoonacular score of 77%. This score is pretty good. Similar recipes are Grilled Swordfish Sicilian-Style, Sicilian-style Swordfish, and Swordfish, Sicilian Style.

winePairing.pairingText: Pinot Grigio, Gruener Veltliner, and Pinot Noir are my top picks for Fish. Fish is as diverse as wine, so it's hard to pick wines that go with every fish. A crisp white wine, such as a pinot grigio or Gr√ºner Veltliner, will suit any delicately flavored white fish. Meaty, strongly flavored fish such as salmon and tuna can even handle a light red wine, such as a pinot noir. One wine you could try is Alsace Willm Pinot Gris Reserve. It has 4.4 out of 5 stars and a bottle costs about 16 dollars.

productMatches.title: Alsace Willm Pinot Gris Reserve
productMatches.description: An intense golden color with hints of ocher, the wine has a nose of ripe fruit, quince. In the mouth the attack is both supple and full, with notes of honey and spices. The final perfectly balances sugar and acidity.Pair this wine alongside pan-fried foie gras, grilled or roasted white meats (pork, veal), rabbit, poultry in cream sauce, smoked fish, mushroom dishes such as risotto.

instructions: Preheat grill on high (or preheat the broiler on high).In a small bowl, mix the lemon juice with the salt until the salt dissolves. Stir in the oregano. Slowly whisk in the olive oil and season generously with pepper.Grill the swordfish steaks over high heat (as close to the heat as possible), turning once, until cooked through, 6 to 7 minutes.Transfer the fish to a platter. Prick each fish steak in several places with a fork to allow the sauce to penetrate.Using a spoon, beat the sauce, then drizzle it over the fish.Serve immediately.

steps.step: Preheat grill on high (or preheat the broiler on high).In a small bowl, mix the lemon juice with the salt until the salt dissolves. Stir in the oregano. Slowly whisk in the olive oil and season generously with pepper.Grill the swordfish steaks over high heat (as close to the heat as possible), turning once, until cooked through, 6 to 7 minutes.
Transfer the fish to a platter. Prick each fish steak in several places with a fork to allow the sauce to penetrate.Using a spoon, beat the sauce, then drizzle it over the fish.
